title: Attention processes and dorsal stream function in developmental disorders
abstractText: Attention deficits emerge as key features of many neurodevelopmental disorders, including both Williams syndrome (WS) and Down's syndrome (DS).  However, existing attention measures are often unsuitable for children with developmental delay, and objective assessment of attention in WS and DS has been limited. We have recently developed and normalised a new preschool attention battery for children aged 3-6 years, or children with a mental age in this range.  The current project will use this battery to examine how attention processes are affected in WS and DS.  We will explore whether components of attention found to be separable in typically-developing groups are also separable in WS and DS, and whether they show differential levels of impairment.  We will also explore how attention processes in these children are related to functions of the dorsal and ventral visual streams. Dorsal stream functioning, involved in visuo-spatial processing and guiding action, is known to be impaired in a number of developmental disorders.  We will examine whether this 'dorsal stream vulnerability' is related to problems of attention.  Results will provide a much needed insight into the specifics of attention impairment in WS and DS, informing cognitive and developmental literatures and approaches to education for children with these difficulties.
